ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
MAJLIS UGAMA ISLAM SINGAPURA
(Financial assistance to needy students)


    1. Haji Rahmat bin Kenap asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) how much money had been set aside by the Majlis Ugama Islam for assistance to needy students during the years 1975, 1976, 1977 and 1978 and the amount each student received or will receive; and (b) how many students attending Islam religious classes are receiving this financial aid and how much does each person get.

Column: 1338



     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, financial assistance given by the Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS) to needy Muslim students during the years 1975 to 1978 consist of two main categories, annual bursaries and monthly study grants. The MUIS also provides financial assistance to needy Muslim students to help them purchase textbooks, pay examination fees, transport allowances, etc.

Bursaries

    The quantum of each bursary varies according to the awardee's level of education, his financial background and

Column: 1339

whether he is receiving financial assistance from other sources. Nevertheless, the recommended quantum is as follows:

    Secondary level, $60 per annum;

    Pre-university level, $300 per annum;

    Technical and vocational training level, $500 per annum;

    University undergraduate level, $1,000 per annum; and

    Post-graduate level, $1,500 per annum. Although the MUIS has set aside $100,000 for bursaries this year, the awards will only be made in July 1978 after the selection committee has selected the successful candidates.

    The amount of funds granted by the MUIS for bursaries during the years 1975 to 1977 were $110,300, $93,250 and $98,480 respectively. Of the 500 bursaries awarded during these years, 119 or 23.42% of the awards were given to Muslim students pursuing Muslim religious studies at pre-university, college and university levels.

Study grants and financial assistance

    The MUIS also provides monthly study grants and financial assistance to needy Muslim students. Each study grant is worth $15 per month for students attending full-time classes and $5 per month for those attending pan-time classes. The amount of funds provided for study grants and miscellaneous financial assistance during the years 1975 to 1978 (January and February) were $18,132.50, $19,674, $19,114.15 and $2,900 respectively. Of the 431 study grants awarded during these years, 16 or 3.71% were for Muslim students studying in Muslim religious schools.

Total amount paid between 1975 and 1977

    During the years 1975 to 1977, the MUIS provided a total of $358,950.65 to Muslim students as bursaries, study grants and other miscellaneous forms of financial assistance. $70,765 or 19.71% were for students pursuing Muslim religious studies.

     The Acting Minister for Culture (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in response to the various issues raised by Members in this House last night, I would like to approach the problems from the general to specifics today. First of all, the points raised by the Members for Serangoon Gardens and Jalan Kayu. The questions were: what is culture? what is our cultural policy? Sir, I have asked myself these questions before, and since I stepped into the Ministry of Culture I have made use of the library service under the Ministry to ascertain what culture is. To my disappointment or bewilderment, the library gave me some 300 different interpretations as to what culture is. They include interpretations given by our learned Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr S. Rajaratnam, the Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Mr Lee Khoon Choy,

Column: 1341

including one from President Suharto of Indonesia. To sum it up, UNESCO in one of its studies and documents on cultural policies concluded that there is perhaps no other term with more interpretations than the word "culture". Sir, I have no wish to add another one to the list. The anthropologists and sociologists seem to be experts in this field. They interpret culture to mean the sum total of human achievement and activities and have included within the definition not only the aesthetic such as music, painting, drama, literature and so on, but also political and social realities as well as the material creations of man which mould his thoughts and attitudes. Therefore, the concept of culture embraces all aspects of life. The enormous scope of the subject makes the formulation of culture a very daunting task, daunting because no policy can really satisfy all the elements contained in culture. Yet, a government must have a cultural policy to ensure that the cultural environment is properly nurtured and developed for the health of the whole nation. The formulation of any cultural policy must, of course, take into account the socio-cultural background of the people, in the case of Singaporeans who inherited a very diverse and disparate cultural patterns from their forefathers.

    I do not want to bore Members in this House with the historical background and details which have been explained at length in the past. In short or in brief, the adopted process is to try to harmonise the disparate strands of our cultures by breaking down ethnic shells and educate and spur our people to achieve a common and distinct cultural identity of our own. We did this in the early days by diffusing the communal sentiments and chauvinism which existed during the colonial days. Parallel to this, we are creating a favourable environment for the growth and evolution of the different ethnic cultures in Singapore. The best in our cultural background must be emphasised and promoted. From these origins, a local culture will be and is slowly evolving. A Singapore cultural identity is no longer so elusive now. I believe we have made some headway and

Column: 1342

hope that we will slowly but steadily march towards the full development of a national culture, which is the objective of our cultural policy. But natural evolution is a long and tedious process. Although new cultural forms cannot be laid down precisely in advance, it can be nurtured with the visions of men, with the visions of Singaporeans and with the necessary assistance and encouragement from all quarters, we hope to expedite this process.

    I agree with the Member's view that we should not and cannot preserve indiscriminately all traditional forms regardless of their relationship to present realities and needs. As culture is not a mere museum but a living thing which is preserved, what is preserved must be that part of our heritage that gives us identity and yet strengthen us in dealing with the complex process of living in a modern world. Therefore, alongside the preservation of the old must be the evolution of the new. In the process of promoting better understanding of our culture, there is a need to raise the level of cultural appreciation among our people. One way to achieve this is to encourage the people to participate in cultural activities. Towards this direction, my Ministry will try its best within the usual constraints to broaden and strengthen its range of cultural activities which would be made available to all, and not an elite few. Participating in these activities would either be free of charge or with nominal charge to allow ready access. In the long run, however, the people will decide the pace or momentum of our cultural process. In the meantime, the Government will continue to develop both the infrastructure and the climate for fostering the growth of Singapore cultural identity.
2.45 p.m.

    I share the views of the Members for Serangoon Gardens and Jalan Kayu that there should be better coordination among Government Ministries, departments and statutory bodies in organising cultural activities. I would like to inform them and the House that my Ministry has recently taken measures to coordinate the various cultural

Column: 1343

activities so as to avoid the duplication of effort. In the long term it may be desirable to establish a Council or a Board or a Cultural Agency, as proposed by Members, to ensure that cultural activities of the various groups are complementary and not counter productive. This concept is presently being actively considered by my Ministry.

    The Member for Boon Lay raised a number of points about our television. We are aware of the need to expand and improve services both in respect of our Radio and Television. We will strive to effect this. There are, however, three major constraints, namely, (1) limited finance, (2) inadequate facilities and (3) shortage of trained professional, technical and supporting staff. Notwithstanding these constraints, which we are trying to overcome, every effort will be made to improve the quality and quantity of programmes, both imported and locally produced.

    The Member for Boon Lay expressed the wish to see another television station to be set up in Singapore in order to provide some competition for RTS. His proposition is prompted by his concern for the quality of RTS programmes. His argument is quite valid but given the current constraints I do not see the proposition to be practicable or possible at this stage. There are, of course, other ways of improving the quality of RTS programmes, without having to establish another television station in Singapore.

    With regard to his suggestion to increase the number of television channels to cope with the programmes in four languages, it is necessary for me to explain that the current programme output in four languages depends not on the number of channels or the amount of air time available, but on the availability of programmes and materials, both imported and local. RTS sets fairly high standards in selecting and acquiring foreign programmes for screening. Here I also agree with the Member for Changi that not all foreign programmes, especially those produced in the Western countries, are suitable for local viewers. In view of this, RTS has experienced some difficulty in acquiring

Column: 1344

sufficient suitable programmes to fill the air time. Therefore, there is no plan at the moment to increase the number of channels.

    The Member for Boon Lay also likes to see more live telecast on the television. He cited the Malaysia Cup Soccer matches as one of them which was not telecast live. Public events of national importance have always been telecast live, such as the National Day Parade and Lunar New Year Chingay Procession. With regard to sporting events which are of significant public interest, every effort is made to have them telecast live provided the organisers have no objections.

    Sometimes the impresario and organisers are reluctant to grant permission for live telecast as it may affect the takings at the box office. Likewise in the case of the Malaysia Cup Soccer matches, the Football Association of Malaysia has given strict instruction that they do not want the matches at the National Stadium to be telecast live for fear of affecting the sales of tickets. I am sure the Member will appreciate that this is sometimes quite beyond the control of RTS. Certain shows which are produced by RTS in their studios, especially productions which involve the element of competition such as the Talentime series and the final programme in the Debate series are telecast live. Any other programmes where the viewers are interested in the results are also transmitted live.

    I am pleased to know that the Member for Boon Lay agrees in principle on the need to promote the use of Mandarin. The mass media, the press, television and radio, must play an integral role in reinforcing the use of Mandarin by our young. The mass media, especially television and radio, have the responsibility to ensure that they gear their activities to suit the requirements and goals of the society. Therefore, special attention will have to be given to programmes which exert a strong influence on the formative minds of our younger generation. I agree with the Member that the modern drama films acquired from Hong Kong are generally of a high quality, and that their themes are generally pertinent and wholesome. These

Column: 1345

programmes will be retained. Meanwhile we are looking into the feasibility of dubbing the programmes into Mandarin.

    I also share the Member's concern that there should be adequate provision in the radio broadcast for news and information in dialects to cater to the needs of the older generation. Any modification made in the course will certainly take into account the needs of the older generation to be kept informed of the events taking place in our country and the world at large.

    The Member for Anson raised quite a number of points also. I believe the cultural troupe which the Member for Anson referred to is actually the National Dance Company. Since its establishment in 1971 the troupe of the National Dance Company has been sent or invited to perform overseas on numerous occasions. Apart from this, the Company also put up performances locally at important functions, such as the National Cultural Show and also shows for dignitaries visiting Singapore. I would like to first assure the Member for Anson that RTS is fully aware of its role to nurture the growth of Singapore culture. It has and will continue to discharge this responsibility in various ways. He thought it was a pity that we no longer have the programme "Pesta Pop". "Pesta Pop" has just simply changed its name. It is now called "Pusparama". It is the same show. So there is no loss in the television programme.

    The Member for Anson also complained about soccer matches not fully broadcast over the radio in Tamil. If soccer matches start on time at 7.30 p.m. there will be no problem. But we have no control of the kick-off time for soccer matches in the Malaysia Cup series. Sometimes they start late and sometimes the times are extended. If the matches begin before 7.30 p.m. then RTS is able to broadcast live commentary in the Tamil service as well as in other languages. But if it is delayed, then what they do is to record the commentaries and broadcast them the following day. If there is a large following in the Tamil service, I do not see

Column: 1346

why we should not look into this again. I shall ask RTS to look into the possibility of extending the transmission time of the Tamil Service for transmitting special programmes and events, like the Malaysia Cup Soccer series, for the Tamil speaking soccer fans.

    The Member also complained about the delay in the telecast time of Tamil films. On the whole, the telecast of Tamil feature films has been punctual. The occasional delay is usually due to the fact that among the programmes preceding Tamil cinema are live news bulletins which are extremely difficult to time precisely before transmission. And also on occasions when there are Parliamentary reports, which are also read out live, the transmission of Tamil cinema films and other non-Tamil programmes which follow might be delayed, varying from the advertised time from two to five minutes. These are sometimes inevitable. Generally the programme times given by RTS are published accurately in the newspapers. Only on rare occasions are changes made on the day of transmission itself. When this happens such changes in the programme time are repeatedly publicised over television.

    As regards spacing out the programmes so that Tamil-speaking viewers could watch Tamil cinemas and at the same time do not miss Roots and Six Million Dollar Man or other popular programmes, it is very difficult. It is very difficult to satisfy all the requirements and please everybody. RTS transmits on two channels and in four languages. Somehow someone has to make sacrifices. However, where possible, RTS repeats popular programmes at different times later on so as to make those popular programmes more accessible to our viewers. In the case of Roots, RTS is now negotiating with the distributor of the serial for a repeat showing later this year in a different time slot.
3.00 p.m.

    The Member for Changi has a lot of criticisms on RTS. He wants to see the quality of programmes and local productions improved and increase local production programmes. The standard of RTS TV

Column: 1347

production cannot really be assessed along the same criteria as those produced, say, in the studios of Hollywood. Looking just at the production budget, a one-hour episode of action drama series like the Six Million Dollar Man or musicals like Donny and Marie Show cost these studios in the region of $900,000 whereas our annual budget for local production is $680,000. In other words, our annual budget is only 75% of that required to produce a one-hour Hollywood drama or musical episode. As I mentioned earlier, these are the existing constraints with which RTS operates and these are the constraints that we are now actively trying to overcome.

    On the staffing of RTS, training programmes and so on, so far, 10 members of the staff of RTS at the level of executive producers and producers have been sent overseas for training in programme production. Executive producers have on their return conducted training courses for other members of the production staff. There is a great deal our producers and designers can learn from going abroad and studying methods and techniques being used by the more advanced stations. In March 1976, an expert from the BBC was attached to RTS under the Colombo Plan scheme for a period of 18 months to conduct a series of training courses for TV producers, floor managers, script assistants and other staff engaged in production work. The course run by this expert has contributed to the improvement of local productions. But training has to be carried out on a continuous basis. This is only possible if there are, on the establishment, staff specifically recruited to initiate training schemes. It is not feasible to continually rely on the secondment of overseas experts as these experts may not always be available.

    The Member is also critical about the comic sketch put up by our Armed Forces in our variety show. I personally do not see much harm done. These comic sketches do not necessarily reflect or adversely affect the quality of our Armed Forces. In fact, it is a good thing to be able to laugh at ourselves sometimes, at our own awkwardness and -absurdities. Some may regard this as a sign of maturity, namely, our ability to poke fun at

Column: 1348

one another, at the Government and at society generally. His suggestion that all programmes in Mandarin should have Chinese sub-titles is not a bad one but I do not know whether RTS, with the present staffing resources, is able to do this just yet. Anyway, I will convey his request to RTS to look into this possibility.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu)( In Mandarin): Sir, the Member for Changi has suggested that we should increase the number and upgrade the quality of locally produced programmes. The Minister in his explanation said that they have acknowledged that there is such a need but the problem is the question of finance. As far as I understand it, apart from finance, the more basic question is attitude. In scheduling the programmes RTS seems to look down upon the locally produced programmes. Most of the artistes who perform in the programme Musical Showcase are from abroad. Does this mean that we do not have sufficient local artistes to perform in this programme? As a matter of fact, in my opinion, our standard of production and our local talent are not inferior to those from foreign countries. For example, the programme My Home in Toa Payoh is quite popular and well received. In fact, the Malay programme Pusparama is of a very high standard. The standard of this programme is higher than that of Musical Showcase. However, I believe the artistes in this programme Pusparama are mostly local artistes. Why then should we engage foreign artistes from Taiwan to perform in programmes like Musical Showcase? I do not agree that it is only a question of finance. It is basically a question of attitude.

    Just now, the Minister said that in our cultural endeavours we do not have a central agency to coordinate all our cultural activities. Therefore, we cannot fully utilise our local talents and after their return to Singapore from overseas they would find that their talents are not being made use of here. They are therefore compelled to go overseas to seek employment. This is also a form of brain drain. I hope the Ministry of Culture would make an in-depth study of this problem and seek a solution to it.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, I just want to ask the Minister one question. In his reply, the Minister admitted that one TV station operating two channels is not enough and that someone has to make some sacrifice. He also admitted that the setting up of another TV station will provide healthy competition leading to home viewers having more exciting and meaningful programmes. But he also mentioned that due to financial constraints the Government is not prepared at this stage to set up another TV station. Under these circumstances would the Government consider allowing the private sector to run a second TV station?

     Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, the reply by the Senior Minister of State regarding the Tamil programmes is reasonable. My only complaint is that the time for the telecast of Tamil films is not punctual. If it is published at 10.15 p.m. why is it telecast at 10.20 p.m.? Why must we wait for 5 minutes?

    I also wish to inform the Minister that there is discrimination regarding Tamil programmes. The Minister is a very reasonable man and he can check up whether the Broadcasting Department is making a discrimination. Whenever there is a function in my constituency, they never send any TV cameraman. That is discrimination. I do not want any publicity but there should not be any discrimination. There was no TV coverage for Metric exhibition at the Nelson Road Market. The Ministry of Culture only sent a photographer. That is all right. But I do not want discrimination between Indians and other races. Ours is a multi-racial society. The Minister should check this up and tell the Broadcasting Department not to discriminate. If they cannot do the job, they should hand it over to the proper man to do it. That is my request. The Minister's reply is very reasonable but I want to see certain things done in the Broadcasting Department.

     Mr Ngeow Pack Hua (Boon Lay)( In Mandarin): Sir, in his reply to the Member for Changi just now the Senior Minister of State said thai he did not think that the comic sketches performed by the Armed Forces

Drama Company would do us any harm. I do not agree with the Senior Minister of State. I wonder whether the Senior Minister of State has seen such farcical dramatic sketches which not only contain vulgar vernacular and play but the contents are also of rather low nature that would cast a slur on the image of our armed forces. There were dirty words and mean action calculated to be offensive to women folk. The less this kind of sketches is shown by RTS, the better.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): In his reply, the Senior Minister of State mentioned that a distinctive Singaporean cultural identity can only be established through evolution by a gradual process and that this cultural identity cannot be established by a deliberate attempt to dictate what it should be. I agree with him. Nevertheless, it may be useful for the Ministry to consider a publication wherein the Ministry can define and explain in simple terms the salient aspects of our cultural heritage. This will be useful for the information and education of the children and young adults. If this suggestion is taken up, I hope that in this effort the Ministry will deal with the more relevant and serious aspects of our culture and not the frivolous presentations that are contained in the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board's publications.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, to some extent, I agree with the comments of the Member for Jalan Kayu that our local productions are not really that poor. But there is always room for improvement. His criticism on our variety show being over-dependent on foreign artistes is not entirely true. We have local artistes participating in this programme also. We will look into the possibility of reducing the foreign artiste content in this programme in the future. In fact, my Ministry has plans to have another programme consisting mainly of local and young budding artistes, especially those who came into the finals of local song and music contests. This programme will consist wholly of local content and will be available to viewers soon.

3.15 p.m.

    The question of constraints is not entirely a financial one. Financial constraint is only part of it. But it is mainly the manpower constraint. It is like starting a new university; you must have the professors and lecturers. It is the same with the RTS. As it is, there is already a shortage of staff, and not all the vacancies are filled. The good personnel are running away. This is a perennial problem which we have to constantly look into. We should perhaps look into the question of revising the scales and rates of pay that we pay to the artistes.

    The question of considering the possibility of allowing private TV stations to be established in Singapore does not really arise because no one has yet made that proposal. When the time comes we will consider the matter.

    The Member for Boon Lay is entitled to his views. If the matter is serious enough to warrant a check on productions made by the Armed Forces personnel, the best thing to do is to bring this to the attention of the Minister of Defence. Whether RTS should allow this programme to be telecast is a subjective one. So far we have not had many complaints on this. It is purely meant to entertain. As an entertaining programme, it does not necessarily reflect badly on the Armed Forces. Sometimes it is good to be able to laugh at their own absurdities and awkwardness, the problems that they have in the Army. I know the Americans have a television programme called Phil Silvers Show It pokes fun at the Army generals and Army personnel. That does not necessarily reflect the quality of the US Army.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens has made a suggestion on the possibility of puffing up a publication to define and explain the salient features of our cultural heritage. It is perhaps high time too that we took stock of our resources and of our cultural heritage by collating data to establish the yardstick of our cultural evolution up to this stage, so to speak, to see in what direction we are going. I agree that such publications may be useful.

I do not know whether at the present moment the Ministry of Culture has the resources to do this or when it will be produced. I cannot promise him at this stage. I will definitely look into the matter.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when we talk about education, we are in fact dealing with the future. And when we talk about culture, we are in fact dealing with the very foundation of that future. Yet the future is not that simple to ascertain. But we are still very lucky simply because the future has one vital advantage and that is the experiences of the past and the reality of today. From this advantage we can map the future. And the future means constant change. This constant change becomes our constant challenge, whether the change is endogenous, exogenous, episodic or even patterned.

Column: 1353



    The exogenous change is usually the culmination of the cultural onslaught from outside. It is a threat to the very fabric of one's culture, to our culture for that matter. The progress we have achieved will be jeopardised should the aesthetic value of this important aspect of life be neglected. Without alertness and proper checking the undesirable elements of outside culture will penetrate our society, especially the young, with new undesirable values, which could result in the evolving of a new CCC, only this time it is not the Citizens' Consultative Committee but the Cargo Cult Community, or as a good friend of mine has said, the "Coca Cola Culture".
